[[AIDA - International Association of Arabic Dialectology|AIDA]]
[[IALS]] |athletics = 12 Varsity Teams |website =http://www.kozminski.edu.pl/en/ |address =57/59 Jagiellońska St., 03-596 Warsaw, POLAND }} [[File:Akademia Leona Koźmińskiego 2014 01.JPG|thumb|Part of Kozminski University campus]] '''Kozminski University''' (formerly known as ''Leon Kozminski Academy of Entrepreneurship and Management'', in Polish ''Akademia Leona Koźmińskiego'') is a private[https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bushor.2018.03.010/ Kaplan Andreas (2018) A school is “a building that has four walls…with tomorrow inside”: Toward the reinvention of the business school, Business Horizons], [[non profit]] [[business school]] in [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]], and is considered to be "Poland’s highest rated private university".[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/02aeb39e-bce3-11dd-af5a-0000779fd18c.html#axzz1dykecJJJ Cienski, Jan (2008) "School profile: Kozminski University", ''Financial Times'' online] It was established in 1993 and named after Leon Koźmiński, a Polish professor of [[economics]] and [[entrepreneurship]], and also the father of [[Andrzej Koźmiński]] - the founder and the first [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the school. It is one of the top business schools in the world, the Central Eastern campus of [[ESCP]] as of 2015[http://www.kozminski.edu.pl/en/about-kozminski/strategic-alliance-escp-europe-kozminski-university/ Strategic alliance between ESCP Europe and KU], and the only institution of higher education in Poland, holding the [[triple accreditation|"triple crown accreditation (EQUIS, AMBA, AACSB)"]]. Less than 1% of business education providers worldwide hold these three major international quality accreditations. The Financial Times Financial Times Ranking – 2014 named the University as the best business schools in Poland and Central Europe. '''Academics''' The school runs programs in Polish and in English at [[bachelor]], [[Master's degree|master]], [[postgraduate]], [[MBA]] and [[doctorate]] levels in [[management]], [[finance]], [[law]], [[European studies]], [[sociology]], [[psychology in management]] and [[Administration (business)|administration]]. As of 2011, it is the only private business school in Poland with full [[doctorate]] (since 1998) and [[habilitation]] (since 2003) granting rights in [[management]]. It is also entitled by the Ministry of Science and Higher Education to grant PhD titles in law and economics (since 2009). '''Accreditations''' In 1999 Kozminski University was the first business school in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]] to receive [[EQUIS]] accreditation. In 2005 the accreditation was extended to the full, unconditional one. Kozminski University was also the first business school in [[Central Europe|Central]] and [[Eastern Europe]] accredited by [[AACSB]] (since 2011[http://www.aacsb.edu/media/releases/2011/accreditation_kozminski.asp KOZMINSKI UNIVERSITY BECOMES THE FIRST SCHOOL IN POLAND TO EARN AACSB INTERNATIONAL ACCREDITATION - AACSB announcement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504012712/http://www.aacsb.edu/media/releases/2011/accreditation_kozminski.asp |date=2012-05-04 }}), [[Association of MBAs|AMBA]],[http://www.ambaguide.com/find-an-accredited-programme/schools/eastern-europe-and-russia/kozminski-university/ AMBA guide] and [[CEEMAN]]. Kozminski University is also the only business school in Poland accredited with distinction by National Accreditation Committee.[http://www.rp.pl/artykul/131023,660102-Najlepsi-w-Europie-Srodkowej.html?p=1 "najlepsi w Europie Środkowej" (''The best in Central Europe'') a newspaper article in "Rzeczpospolita", 19 May 2011] In addition, the university is a full member of ELFA (European Law Faculties Association) and EUA (European University Association). ==History== * March 1993 - Minister of Education entered the School of Entrepreneurship and Management in the register of non-state universities. * October 1993 - The University obtained the right to education at the undergraduate majoring in management and marketing. * 1996 - The power to conduct consistent and complementary degree majoring in management and marketing. * 1997 - Eligibility to undergraduate majoring in finance and banking. * 1998 - The decision to launch a new field of study: administration . The Central Commission for Scientific Titles and Degrees awarded the University the right to confer the degree of doctor of economic sciences in the field of management science. * 1999 - European Foundation for Management Development EFMD awarded EQUIS accreditation Kozminski University - European Quality Improvement (European Quality Improvement System. KU was the 16th business school in Europe to be accredited by EQUIS. * 2000 - Decision of the Bureau of the Conference of Rectors of Academic Schools in Polish Kozminski Academy was granted the status of university membership CRASP, as the only non-public university in this group . * 2001 - Kozminski Academy gained the power to conduct a five-year master's programs in law and the powers to pursue graduate studies in finance and banking. * 2002 - Eligibility to graduate majoring in administration. * 2003 - Eligibility to higher professional studies in sociology. Decision of the Central Commission for Academic Degrees and Titles Academy of Entrepreneurship and Management. Kozminski University was granted the rights issue the postdoctoral degree in economic sciences in the discipline of management science. * 2004 - The psychology of management and European studies programs are launched. Kozminski Academy is granted rights for doctoral studies in management. * 2005 - The University received the confirmation for unconditional accreditation of EQUIS - the European Quality Improvement System. * 2006 - Professor Witold ceremony of conferring an honorary doctorate Kieżun Kozminski Academy of Entrepreneurship and Management . Kozminski University (Poland's first honorary doctorate awarded by the University nonpublic). * 2008 - The Central Commission for Academic Degrees and Titles decided to grant the Academy of Management and Entrepreneurship Kozminski authority to confer the degree of doctor of economic sciences in the discipline of economics. Moreover, the university has been accredited by AMBA for MBA programs. The minister of Science and Higher Education gave the university permission to conduct second degree in sociology and changed the name of the university from Academy of Management and Entrepreneurship Kozminski to Kozminski University . * 2009 – Kozminski University received authorization to conduct studies I and II degree in economics. In addition, the Central Commission for Academic Degrees and Titles decided to grant permission Kozminski University to award the degree of Doctor of Law in the discipline of law. * 2013 – Kozminski University obtained the rights to award PhD degrees in the field of finance. == Awards and rankings== Kozminski University has been highly ranked by many international and domestic university rankings. ===Financial Times rankings=== * European Business Schools '''41st in 2014''' (37th in 2013, 37th in 2012,[http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/kozminski-university-warsaw/european-business-school-rankings-2014#european-business-school-rankings-2014 "Financial Times" school profile, source ft.com]). * Masters in Finance Pre-experience '''21st in 2014''' (19th in 2013, 21st in 2012,[http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/kozminski-university-warsaw/masters-in-finance-pre-experience-2014#masters-in-finance-pre-experience-2014 "Financial Times" school profile, source ft.com]). * Masters in Management '''35th in 2014''' (25th in 2013, 28th in 2012,[http://rankings.ft.com/businessschoolrankings/kozminski-university-warsaw/masters-in-management-2014#masters-in-management-2014 "Financial Times" school profile, source ft.com]). ===Eduniversal ranking=== Ranks amongst the best 1,000 business schools in 154 countries by region and country. * Kozminski University '''2nd place in 2014 with four palms''' as "Top Business School" (2nd in 2013, 2nd in 2012, 2nd in 2011{{cite web|last1=Eduniversal|title=Kozminski University|url=http://www.eduniversal-ranking.com/business-school-university-ranking-in-poland/kozminski-university.html?year=2014|website=http://www.eduniversal-ranking.com|accessdate=2015-02-10|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210093916/http://www.eduniversal-ranking.com/business-school-university-ranking-in-poland/kozminski-university.html?year=2014|archivedate=2015-02-10|df=}}). ==Student life== '''Campus''' Kozminski's 3.4 hectare campus consists of four buildings (A,B, C and D) with a total area of approximately 20,000 square meters. It is located in [[Praga Północ]] a north-eastern district of Warsaw. The school has 6 large auditoriums (each seating between 100 and 200 people) as well as 26 classrooms (seating 50 to 100 people) and 24 workshop classrooms (seating up to 50 people). Larger classrooms and all auditoriums possess audio-visual equipment. The school owns 5 seminar and discussion group rooms, as well as a Senate Hall (seating 120 people), 4 computer labs and 2 server rooms. The 3 cafeterias are available for faculty and students and are located on the premises as well as a bookstore, 2 photocopying offices, 5 coffee machines, a cash machine, a post office, 5 student organization offices and 3 guest apartments for visiting faculty members. Furthermore, there are 98 fully equipped faculty and administration offices. ==Publisher== Kozminski University is the publisher of a quarterly academic journal the ''[[Management and Business Administration. Central Europe (journal)|Management and Business Administration. Central Europe]]''.[http://mbace.eu/ Management and Business Administration. Central Europe] "MBA.CE" is a national scientific periodical about management in public and private sector institutions. The periodical is a dialogue platform for scientists and practicians. "MBA. CE" includes articles regarding the following fields: human resource management, theory of organization, strategic management, corporate order, managerial economy, accounting and finance. The articles can be based in such disciplines as economy, psychology, sociology or law. Moreover, MBA. CE" is included in the list of periodicals receiving 8 points from the Ministry of Science and Higher Education. == Partner universities == Kozminski University collaborates with more than 200 partner universities,{{cite web|last1=Kozminski|title=Partner Universities|url=http://www.kozminski.edu.pl/en/about-kozminski/international/partner-universities/|website=http://www.kozminski.edu.pl/en|accessdate=2015-02-10}} where students can spend one or more semesters of their study program. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.kozminski.edu.pl/en/}} {{coord|52.2714|21.0150|format=dms|display=title|type:edu_region:PL}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:1993 establishments in Poland]] [[Category:Business schools in Poland]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Warsaw]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1993]]

Kuwait Chamber of Commerce and Industry (KCCI) |nativename = غرفة تجارة وصناعة الكويت |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo =Emblem of Kuwait.svg |logo_width =150px |logo_caption =[[Emblem of Kuwait]] |jurisdiction = |headquarters = [[Kuwait City]] {{flagicon|Kuwait}} |coordinates = {{Coord|29|22|18|N|47|58|53|E|display=title}} |chief1_name = - Ali Al Ghanem |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = - Khaled Al Sager |chief2_position = 1st Vice President |chief3_name = - Abdul Wahab Al Wazzan |chief3_position = 2nd Vice President |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw }} '''Kuwait Chamber of Commerce and Industry''' (KCCI) ({{lang-ar| الكويت غرفة التجارة والصناعة}}) is a non-government institution representing business establishments in [[Kuwait]]. The Chamber acts on the behalf of, represents and lobbies for the interests of businesspersons and industrialists in Kuwait. ==History== The establishment of a Chamber of Commerce was first mooted in 1952. Three years later in 1955 the Chamber was established and in 1959, the election of the Chamber’s first [http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw/echamber/website/index.jsp?pageID=ws_boardmembers.jsp&ajax=yes&sessionID=0a01320750954ed9f1b15a475c809ed515cf8c7dc0&pageID=ws_boardmembers.jsp&scriptPage=index.jsp Board of Directors] took place. KCCI is a truly democratic organisation. The members of the Board of Directors are all elected and its leading figures are known for their contribution to industry and business.During that time, the hearts of the citizens were ready to comprehend every nice and great achievement. The KCCI growth kept in line with the country’s growth and luxury.[http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/149749/reftab/69/Default.aspx The Kuwait Chamber Of Commerce And Industry Is Not Just A Huge Commercial Fort But A Lofty Democratic Fort.] ''Arab Times''. Retrieved 30 September 2014. ==About KCCI== KCCI is a non-profit, self-financed private institution. Currently the registered members exceeds 79000 and represents the general assembly. The general assembly elects 24 members for the Board of Directors for a period of 4 years, half of whom are elected every two years. Subscriptions and authentication fees are the main resources of income. The President and the Board Members are considered volunteers for public services. The Chamber is a consultative entity in all economic affairs.[http://www.kuwait-info.com/a_economy/industry_KCCI.asp KCCI] Kuwait. Retrieved 30 September 2014. ==Branches== There are seven branches for KCCI # [http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw/echamber/website/index.jsp?pageID=ws_branches.jsp&ajax=yes&sessionID=0a01320750954ed9f1b15a475c809ed515cf8c7dc0&branchCode=1&pageID=ws_branches.jsp&language=en&scriptPage=index.jsp Main Branch, Kuwait City] # [http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw/echamber/website/index.jsp?pageID=ws_branches.jsp&ajax=yes&sessionID=0a01320750954ed9f1b15a475c809ed515cf8c7dc0&branchCode=2&pageID=ws_branches.jsp&language=en&scriptPage=index.jsp Ministries Complex, Kuwait City] # [http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw/echamber/website/index.jsp?pageID=ws_branches.jsp&ajax=yes&sessionID=0a01320750954ed9f1b15a475c809ed515cf8c7dc0&branchCode=3&pageID=ws_branches.jsp&language=en&scriptPage=index.jsp Liberation Tower, Kuwait City] # [http://www.kuwaitchamber.org.kw/echamber/website/index.jsp?pageID=ws_branches.jsp&ajax=yes&sessionID=0a01320750954ed9f1b15a475c809ed515cf8c7dc0&branchCode=8&pageID=ws_branches.jsp&language=en&scriptPage=index.jsp Jleeb Al Shuyoukh] # {{Infobox economist | name = Leif Östling | image = Leif Ostling 2012d.JPG | caption = Leif Östling at the distribution of the Gustaf Dalén Medal 2012. | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1945|9|25}} | birth_place = [[Luleå|Luleå, Sweden]] | nationality = [[Sweden]] | institution = [[Chalmers University of Technology]]
[[Gothenburg School of Business, Economics and Law]] }} '''Leif Albert Östling''' (born 25 September 1945) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[chief executive officer]] and former head of the [[Scania AB|Scania AB truck company]], owned by the German [[Volkswagen Group]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.eqtpartners.com/Organization/Others/Leif-Ostling1/|publisher=EQT|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.svensktnaringsliv.se/om_oss/ledamoter/leif-ostling-cv-englishpdf_648327.html/BINARY/Leif%20Östling%20CV%20English.pdf|publisher=Svenskt Näringsliv|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling – resan från Luleå till industritoppen|url=http://www.nsd.se/nyheter/lulea/leif-ostling-resan-fran-lulea-till-industritoppen-nm4685664.aspx|publisher=NSD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=408772&ticker=VLKAY|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania CEO Hints At Counter Bid|url=https://www.forbes.com/2006/12/06/scania-man-volkswagen-markets-equity-cx_po_1206markets12.html#6815a8bb382d|publisher=Forbes|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania President and CEO Leif Östling: Deregulation is creating new market conditions in Europe|url=https://www.scania.com/group/en/scania-president-and-ceo-leif-ostling-deregulation-is-creating-new-market-conditions-in-europe/|publisher=Scania|accessdate=8 April 2018}} In spring 2016, he was appointed Chairman of the [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise]], a post he left in advance in [[November]] 2017.{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordförande Leif Östling avgår|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/leif-ostling-avgar|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Leif Östling lämnar ordförandeposten i Svenskt Näringsliv|url=https://www.svensktnaringsliv.se/kommentaren/leif-ostling-lamnar-ordforandeposten-i-svenskt-naringsliv_690105.html|publisher=Confederation of Swedish Enterprise|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Head of Swedish industry group quits after tax comments|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/sweden-ostling/head-of-swedish-industry-group-quits-after-tax-comments-idUSL8N1NS1NQ|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling has become known as a controversial [[political entrepreneur]] debater who makes bold statements.{{cite web|title=Östling är en frispråkig punkare iklädd kostym|url=https://www.svd.se/ostling-ar-en-frisprakig-punkare-ikladd-kostym|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=sv}} Over the years, he has separated politically from the time of youth when he belonged to the [[Swedish Social Democratic Youth League|Swedish Social Democratic Youth League, SSU]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling – industrins frispråkige tungviktare|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/inrikes/leif-ostling-inustrins-frisprakige-tungviktare|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Landets mest långlivade vd|url=https://www.svd.se/landets-mest-langlivade-vd|publisher=SvD Näringsliv|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Det blir ingen lagstiftning om lönerna|url=http://www.ystadsallehanda.se/ledare/det-blir-ingen-lagstiftning-om-lonerna/|publisher=Ystad Allehanda|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} ==Education and working life== Östling was born in [[Luleå]]. After graduating with a [[Master of Engineering|Master of Engineering degree (M.Eng.)]] from the [[Chalmers University of Technology|Chalmers University of Technology, Sweden]], and a [[Bachelor of Economics|Bachelor of Economics degree (BEcon)]] from [[Gothenburg School of Business, Economics and Law]], he came in 1972 to the Scania AB division in [[Saab-Scania]], where he advanced through a variety of positions. Among other things, he was responsible for long-term planning before he was appointed head of Scania AB in the [[Netherlands]] in 1983. In 1989 he was appointed head of the Scania and in 1994 when Scania broke out of the [[Saab Scania|Saab Scania group]] and became an independent corporation, he was appointed CEO.{{cite web|title=Board of directors|url=http://www.skf.com/my/our-company/organization/corporate-governance/board-of-directors/index.html|publisher=SKF|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling left his post as CEO of [[Volkswagen Commercial Vehicles]] (which includes Scania AB) 2012 in connection with controversial statements that trade unions have no right of veto for a possible relocation of jobs.{{cite web|title=Leif Östling går emot fackens vetorätt|url=https://www.svd.se/leif-ostling-gar-emot-fackens-vetoratt/om/leif-ostling|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling continued on 1 September 2012 to a position in Volkswagen AG until September 2015.{{cite web|title=Leif Östling Joins Modular Management Board|url=https://modularmanagement.com/about-us/news/|publisher=Modular Management|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Veteranen tar ut svängarna|url=https://weekend.di.se/intervjuer/veteranen-tar-ut-svangarna|publisher=Di Weekend|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} When Scania's former main investor [[Investor AB]] in the year of 2000 agreed that Scania AB would merge with their biggest competitor [[Volvo Trucks]], Östling opposed that merger, just as in the fall of 2006 he had opposed German [[MAN SE|MAN's]] plans to buy Scania AB. When the [[EU Commission]], referring to the [[European Union competition law]] ([[Volvo Trucks]] / [[Scania AB]] would practically have a monopoly on the truck market in the [[Nordic countries]]), stopped the merger between [[Volvo Trucks]] and [[Scania AB]],{{cite web|title=The Commission prohibits Volvo's acquisition of its main competitor Scania|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-00-257_en.htm|publisher=European Commission, EU|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Östling won that battle and was able, with support from Scania's new owner [[Volkswagen]], to remain in Scania as [[CEO]]. Also, the [[MAN SE]] bid for takeover was rejected by the main shareholders,{{cite web|title=Scania shareholders reject MAN bid|url=https://www.ft.com/content/346cd5a0-467a-11db-ac52-0000779e2340|publisher=Finacial Times|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Scania board members reject VW-bid - Radio Sweden|url=http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=2054&artikel=5812440|publisher=Sveriges Radio|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=en}} and Östling could continue as CEO after the Annual general meeting in May 2007.{{cite web|title=Scania Minutes of the general meeting|url=https://www.scania.com/group/en/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2015/09/Scania_AGM2007_Minutes__tcm10-164981_tcm40-50041.pdf|publisher=Scania|accessdate=8 April 2018}} ==Controversies== In 2017 Östling participated in the [[SVT]] TV program ''[[Uppdrag granskning]]'', which showed that he had placed money abroad to avoid [[Taxation in Sweden|Swedish taxation]].{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordförande har förmögenhet utomlands|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/granskning/ug/svenskt-naringslivs-ordforande-har-formogenhet-utomlands|publisher=SVT|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Swedish business boss steps down in 'what do I get for my taxes' row|url=https://www.thelocal.se/20171122/swedish-business-boss-leif-ostling-steps-down-in-what-do-i-get-for-my-tax-money-row|publisher=The Local|accessdate=8 April 2018}} Also his comment in connection with that, "Here you pay 20-30 million a year, what the hell do I get for the money?", was considered inappropriate from a chairman of the [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise]].{{cite web|title=Swedish Business Chairman Resigns Amid Paradise Papers Link|url=https://www.icij.org/investigations/paradise-papers/swedish-business-chairman-leif-ostling-resigns-amid-paradise-papers-link/|publisher=ICIJ|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Svenskt Näringslivs ordf: Vad fan får jag?|url=https://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/a/kqz5k/svenskt-naringslivs-ordf-vad-fan-far-jag|publisher=Aftonbladet|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling commented later on the following discussion with "We have got a very narrow sense of corridor in Sweden if all political parties consider the political system to have unlimited taxation rights without the right of citizens to question how the money is used."{{cite web|title=Industrinestorn talar ut om hoten|url=https://weekend.di.se/intervjuer/industrinestorn-talar-ut-om-hoten|publisher=Di Weekend|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} Östling has said that he believes it is "genetically conditioned" that so few women enter the engineering profession. He has also expressed his belief that the threat of [[global warming]] has been exaggerated and that the phenomenon is possibly caused by natural processes, which completely opposes the consensus in the research community that the current climate change is caused by human activity.{{cite web|title=Sju klassiska Leif Östling-citat|url=https://www.svd.se/sju-klassiska-leif-ostling-citat#sida-3|publisher=SvD|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Scientific consensus: Earth's climate is warming|url=https://climate.nasa.gov/scientific-consensus/|publisher=Global Climate Change, Nasa|accessdate=8 April 2018}} ==Prizes and awards== *In 2003, he was awarded an honorary doctorate at [[KTH|KTH, Stockholm]] and at [[Luleå University of Technology|Luleå University of Technology, Luleå]].{{cite web|title=List of honorary doctors at Luleå University of Technology since 1981|url=https://www.ltu.se/research/akh/Hedersdoktorer/Forteckning-over-hedersdoktorer-vid-Lulea-tekniska-universitet-sedan-1981-1.96410?l=en|publisher=Luleå University of Technology|accessdate=8 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Honorary doctors at KTH|url=https://www.kth.se/en/om/fakta/fame/hedersdoktorer/hedersdoktorer-vid-kth-1.3974|publisher=KTH|accessdate=8 April 2018}} *In 2004, he was elected as a member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences]].{{cite web|title=Leif Östling får IVAs Stora guldmedalj|url=https://www.iva.se/publicerat/leif-ostling-far-ivas-stora-guldmedalj/|publisher=Iva|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} *In 2009, he was appointed by [[Veckans Affärer]] 2008 years social capitalist.{{cite web|title=Han är årets sociala kapitalist|url=https://www.va.se/nyheter/2009/05/11/han-ar-arets-sociala-kapitalist/|publisher=Veckans Affärer|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Scania-vd årets sociala kapitalist|url=https://www.dn.se/ekonomi/scania-vd-arets-sociala-kapitalist/|publisher=Dagens Nyheter|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} *In 2012, he was awarded [[Gustaf Dalén|Gustaf Dalén Medal]] by "Chalmersska Ingenjörsföreningen".{{cite web|title=Gustaf Dalén föreläsningen|url=http://www.cing.chalmers.se/News.aspx?oID=21710|publisher=Chalmersska Ingenjörsföreningen|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}}{{cite web|title=Gustaf Dalénmedaljen|url=http://www.cing.chalmers.se/om-oss/gustaf-daln/20879/Page|publisher=Chalmersska Ingenjörsföreningen|accessdate=8 April 2018|language=Swedish}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority '''Nashwa Al Ruwaini''' is a prominent and highly recognized Arab businesswoman who has vast experience in the media field and a career history that has led to her being acknowledged over the years as a best-in-class leading media and business excellence personality.
In terms of her business achievements she is currently Board Member and CEO of Pyramedia – Media Production and Consultancy, CEO of [[Al Joude Investments]], CEO of Al Joude Advertising and Publicity, as well as CEO of Delma Medical Centre. Al Ruwaini is also the Founder and Chairman of the Nashwa Foundation, a charity that is dedicated to philanthropic work across the Arab world.
Her award-winning company Pyramedia is renowned in the Middle East for having produced several significant and popular television shows that have been aired across the region and recognized for their success. Of these shows the most viewed was The Millions Poet and Prince of Poets, which are cultural shows that have helped to preserve Arab poetic culture and heritage, a cause Al Ruwaini is extremely dedicated to.
Nashwa Al Ruwaini is also the Founder and Board Member of the [[Middle East Film Festival]], [[Abu Dhabi]] which was later renamed the Abu Dhabi Film Festival – a very well-received film event that had global reach and the presence of international film personalities participating every year. Additionally she was appointed member of the jury for the International Digital Emmy and is an appointed member of the International Academy of Television Arts and Sciences in the United States. In addition she pioneered the Muslims on Screen and Television, a project that aims to improve and correct the image of Muslims on television and in films all across the globe.
Using her strength in media consulting, Al Ruwaini has a very strong portfolio of government and private sector clients spanning across the Middle East that she provides counsel to. These include the Executive Council, Abu Dhabi, the Abu Dhabi Authority for Culture and Heritage (UAE), Environment Agency-Abu Dhabi (UAE), Emirate of Ajman Culture and Media Department (UAE), the Saudi Ministry of Media and Culture, Qatar Media Company and Egyptian Radio and Television Union. She has also consulted for Hollywood’s famous movies, such as Kingdom of Heaven, Pirates of the Caribbean, Syriana and Aladin.
Nashwa al Ruwaini has an extensive career history in the media as both a presenter, producer and executive producer in several countries in the Middle East, and she has received a multitude of awards for her work.
Her most famous shows that she presented were broadcast on MBC and Dubai TV. Nashwa which was an extremely popular social show on Dubai TV landed her the title of ‘Oprah of the Middle East’ because of her capability to discuss and highlight social issues fearlessly and with no boundaries. The Nashwa show led to her receiving a Gold Award for Best Talk Show, and she was also nominated twice for the Rose D’Or Awards in Switzerland within the category for Best Entertainer and was the first Arab to be nominated for the title. The Nashwa show was also nominated for the Social Award category at the Rose D’Or Awards.
On MBC Al Ruwaini presented several shows over the years such as: Kalam Nawaem, Kashf il Mastour, Good Morning Arabs, Good Evening Arabs, Be Honest with Nashwa and An Evening with an Artistic Celebrity. Her presence on television on these successful and highly viewed shows led to her recognition as an acclaimed media personality in the region.
In the Middle East she was voted as Best Arab Presenter in 1997 and 1998 by Sharq Al Awsat Newspaper in addition to winning within the category of Best Arab Presenter by Al Sada magazine. She was also selected as the Best Arab Presenter in 1999 by Future TV in Lebanon and Al Mara’a Al Asreya Magazine. In the same year she was also chosen for Best Arab Presenter for her program Wipe Out which was aired on MBC.
During her media career, Al Ruwaini has worked as both a presenter and producer for Qatar Media, where she also established press offices for a variety of competitions such as the Qatar International Tennis Tournament, the Qatar Horse Beauty Contest and the Qatar Sailing Competition. She was also the Founder and Editor-in-Chief of a magazine called Nada.
One of Al Ruwaini’s major achievements is her iconic establishment of MBC Group, a significant media company in the Middle East where her contributions ranged from being the Founder and CEO of the MBC Creative Department, the Founder and CEO of the MBC offices in Egypt and North Africa, the Founder and CEO of the production arm of the MBC Group which was based in Egypt and the Founder of the MBC Company for Technical Facilities. She was also the CEO of the International Business for MBC and the holding company ARA in London. Starting from scratch she helped build MBC into the media powerhouse that it is today. On MBC Nashwa Al Ruwaini has been the producer of several famous shows such as: Ala Waraq, Who Wants to be a Millionaire, Hourouf wa Oulouf, Altabkha Naesa Eh, Yalla Shabab, the No to Terrorism Campaign and Awards on Air.
Nashwa Al Ruwaini was part of the team that established Al Arabiya Channel and was responsible for the branding of the channel as well as the Co-producer of the programs grid of the first year after the launch of the channel.
In Egypt and other Arab countries Al Ruwaini has worked on a plethora of media projects and has developed several business plans including conducting a full media plan to establish and develop the Egyptian Company for Media Production with the goal of transforming Egypt into the Hollywood of the Middle East in collaboration with the Egyptian government and developing the Egyptian Union of Radio and Television. She also worked closely with the Secretary General of the Arab League to establish the Arab Media Resources Initiative to create a unified base in association with all the leading media entities to help refute distortions in the Western media concerning the reality of the Arab world.
In the [[United Arab Emirates]], where Al Ruwaini is currently based, she has contributed to key projects and initiatives such as the Middle East Film Festival hosted in Abu Dhabi, the Al Mahabba Awards Festival and the Prince of Poets Festival. She was also the main arm in establishing the Film Financing Circle, Abu Dhabi Film Commission, developing and supervising the agreement of National Geographic Abu Dhabi for the local government and she has helped plan the launch for private channels in Abu Dhabi.
Similarly she was responsible for analyzing the feasibility of establishing the New York Film Academy in Abu Dhabi, an equipment and supplies company called Live and worked on an agreement between the Environment Agency in Abu Dhabi in collaboration with Prince Phillip of England and ARKive to set up the largest audio-visual archive of wildlife in the world. Al Ruwaini was also the Executive Producer of a feature documentary called Changing Sands – The Story of Abu Dhabi.
==Personality and Leadership Awards==
Al Ruwaini’s successful career has resulted in her being recognized, nominated and awarded by a series of organisations, media channels and by leading personalities across the globe.
She has received The ISO Knight Award and been branded a Knight Woman.
Similarly, Al Ruwaini has been acknowledged by Forbes magazine on more than one occasion and was coined: Most Powerful Women to Watch in 2012, was ranked 23rd on Forbes Most Powerful Arab Woman in 2014 and chosen amongst Forbes Arabia’s 50 Most Powerful Businesswomen in the Arab World, twice in a row. In 2017 she was listed again in Forbes among 100 Most Powerful Arab Businesswomen.
She was selected among the 25 Most Powerful Women in Global Media by the Hollywood Reporter, was nominated in the International TV Personality category at the Association of International Broadcasters Media Excellence Awards in the United Kingdom and called Unstoppable in Media by Femina Magazine in 2016. As a business leader, Nashwa Al Ruwaini has received several excellence awards such as CEO of the Year at the IAIR Awards three years in a row, CEO of the Year in the female category of CEO Middle East 2016, selected among the most 100 Powerful Women by CEO Middle East Magazine for several years running. She was also ranked among the Most Powerful Arab People by Arabian Business in 2011, 2012 and 2013 and in 2017 among The Smartest People in the UAE. In the UAE she has also received several titles such as: Ten Most Powerful Arab Women by Emirates Women Magazine, chosen in Ahlan Magazine among the 100 Most Important and Influential Personalities in the UAE, was called Arab Woman Rising Star at the Women Leaders in the UAE in 2015 and one of the Most Inspirational Women in the UAE in 2016. She also won Women Icon of the Year Award at the Middle East Leadership Awards. Additionally in the UAE in 2017 she won the Emirates Woman Award in the category of Innovation as the Overall Best Performer.
She was honoured by Cambridge University, Middle East branch for her exemplary work and contribution in painting a clearer picture of the Arab world and media and as a result was granted the award of Best Arab Media Personality. Nashwa Al Ruwaini has also received awards for her humanitarian work with women and children from the Rashid Foundation and bestowed her with an honour shield from Dubai Police due to her support for social causes.
==Production Awards==
Nashwa Al Ruwaini has not only been awarded for her business excellence skills, she has also received numerous awards for her shows and productions. She received the Silver and Gold Award at the 14th Gulf Festival for Radio and Television productions and Prince of Poets won the Gold Award for Best Variety Show at the 11th Gulf Festival. One of her famous game show productions, The Buzzer was nominated for the 11th edition of the coveted Digital Studio Awards in 2016 and the Million’s Poet TV Show received the Best Production of the Year and Best Lighting Installation at the Digital Studio Awards. Her pioneering efforts in setting up the Middle East Film Festival led to the event being voted Best Festival in Abu Dhabi by What’s On magazine and her production Son of Babylon won the Amnesty International Award and the Peace Film Award at the 60th Berlin International Film Festival Independent Jury Awards. She also won Best Documentary Award for Okht El Amar: Soad Hosny from Al Ahram Al Arabi magazine and at the 2003 Cannes Film Festival she won Best Short Film Documentary for the film discussing AIDS called They Live Among Us.
==Education==
Al Ruwaini has a BA in English Literature from Qatar University, an MSc in International Politics of Asia and Africa from the University of London and an MPhil from the University of London on the media aspects of the Islamic rhetoric.
==Passions==
Nashwa Al Ruwaini is passionate about television and digital content and is consistently seeking inspiration to develop new ideas for her production company Pyramedia. She loves movies and the filmmaking industry and is an avid promoter of social awareness campaigns for several important social and cultural topics. She loves being actively involved with charity work through the Nashwa Foundation that targets to help women and children across the Middle East. Al Ruwaini is married with three children and her family is one of her main passions.

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} {{Infobox Australian place | type = suburb | name = North Sydney | city = Sydney | state = nsw | image = Lavender bay north sydney.jpg | caption = North Sydney skyline | lga = [[North Sydney Council]] | postcode = 2060 | est = | pop = 7,705 | pop_year = {{CensusAU|2016}} | pop_footnotes =<ref name=Census2016>{{Census 2016 AUS|id=SSC13010|name=North Sydney (State Suburb)|accessdate=4 Jul 2017|quick=on}}</ref> | area = 1.4 | stategov = [[Electoral district of North Shore|North Shore]] | fedgov = [[Division of North Sydney|North Sydney]] | near-nw = [[Crows Nest, New South Wales|Crows Nest]] | near-n = [[Cammeray, New South Wales|Cammeray]] | near-ne = [[Cammeray, New South Wales|Cammeray]] | near-w = [[Waverton, New South Wales|Waverton]] | near-e = [[Neutral Bay, New South Wales|Neutral Bay]] | near-sw = [[McMahons Point, New South Wales|McMahons Point]] | near-s = [[Lavender Bay, New South Wales|Lavender Bay]] | near-se = [[Milsons Point, New South Wales|Milsons Point]] | dist1 = 3 | dir1 = north | location1= [[Sydney CBD]] }}
'''North Sydney''' is a suburb and major district on the [[Lower North Shore (Sydney)|Lower North Shore]] of Sydney, Australia. North Sydney is located 3 kilometres north of the [[Sydney central business district]]<ref>Gregorys Street Directory, Gregorys Publishing Company, 2007</ref> and is the administrative centre for the [[Local government in Australia|local government area]] of [[North Sydney Council]].
==History== [[Indigenous Australian|Aborigines]] on the southern side of [[Port Jackson]] (Sydney Harbour) called the north side ''warung'' which meant ''the other side'', while those on the northern side used the same name to describe the southern side.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Attenbrow |first1=Dr Val |title=Place Names Chart |url=https://australianmuseum.net.au/place-names-chart |website=Australian Museum |publisher=Australian Museum |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref>
The first name used by European settlers was ''Hunterhill'', named after a property owned by [[Thomas Muir of Huntershill]] (1765–1799), a Scottish political reformer. He purchased land in 1794 near the location of north pylon of the [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]] is now located, and built a house which he named after his childhood home. This area north to [[Gore Hill, New South Wales|Gore Hill]] became known as [[St Leonards, New South Wales|St Leonards]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}} The township of St Leonards was laid out in 1836 in what is now North Sydney, bounded by what is now Miller, Walker, Lavender and Berry Streets. By 1846 there were 106 houses here and by 1859, the commercial centre had extended from [[Milsons Point, New South Wales|Milsons Point]] to Miller Street. A bus service operated by Jeremiah Wall ran between Milsons Point and ''North Sydney Shops'', and North Sydney thus developed its own identity.
[[File:Sydney Harbour Bridge under construction North Shore aerial.jpg|thumb|Aerial view of North Sydney during construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.]] The North Sydney municipality was incorporated in 1890 and after naming disputes, ''North Sydney'' was settled upon. The post office which opened in 1854 as St Leonards was changed to North Sydney in 1890. The first public school which opened in 1874 as St Leonards was renamed North Sydney in 1910.<ref>''The Book of Sydney Suburbs'', Compiled by Frances Pollon, Angus & Robertson Publishers, 1990, Published in Australia {{ISBN|0-207-14495-8}}, page 191</ref>
North Sydney underwent a dramatic transformation into a commercial hub in 1971–72. In this period no less than 27 skyscrapers were built.<ref>[http://www.sydneyarchitecture.com/NOR/NOR.htm Sydney Architecture]</ref>
===Trams=== {{main|Trams in Sydney}} The history of the North Sydney tramway system can be divided into three periods – the first from the original opening in 1886 to 1909, when the McMahons Point line opened. The second period covers the time until the Wynyard line was opened across the Sydney Harbour Bridge in 1932, and the third until construction of the Cahill Expressway on the eastern side of Sydney Harbour Bridge and the wider closure of the system in 1962.<ref>D Keenan: ''The North Sydney lines of the Sydney tramway system''. Transit Press November 1987 {{ISBN|0-909338-05-1}}</ref>
The first part of the North Sydney tramway system was a double-track cable tramway which commenced at the original Milsons Point Ferry wharf, located where the north pylon of the Harbour Bridge is now. The line originally extended via Alfred St (now Alfred Street South), Junction St (now Pacific Highway), Blue St and Miller Sts to the [[Ridge Street Tram Depot|engine house and depot in Ridge St.]] It used cable grip cars called "dummies" and un-powered trailer cars.
A feature of these lines was the underground tram terminus at [[Wynyard railway station, Sydney|Wynyard railway station]] (the only one in Australia), and the tracks over the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Trams ran from Blue St, North Sydney over a now-demolished steel arch bridge over the Harbour Bridge Roadway, then over the eastern side of the harbour bridge (now road lanes), through a tram platform at Milsons Point railway station, before descending underground into platforms 1 and 2 of Wynyard station.
===Heritage listings=== [[Image:(1)Woodstock_Pacific_Highway_North_Sydney.jpg|''Woodstock'' (1870), one of the last 19th century homes on the Pacific Highway, was the home of John Brown, an early settler in the area|thumb]] [[File:HSBC, North Sydney (6305383585).jpg|thumb|right|[[HSBC]] Building (built in the 1920s)]] North Sydney has a number of heritage-listed sites, including those listed on the [[New South Wales State Heritage Register]]: * 36 Blue Street: Former [[North Sydney Technical High School]] (now Greenwood Hotel)<ref name=nswshr-517>{{cite NSW SHR|5045453|North Sydney Technical High School (former)|hr=00517|fn=S90/03327 & HC 32139|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> * 20 Edward Street: ''[[Graythwaite]]''<ref name=nswshr-1617>{{cite NSW SHR|5051393|Graythwaite|hr=01617|fn=S90/03212|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref><ref>http://majorprojects.planning.nsw.gov.au/index.pl?action=view_job&job_id=4267</ref><ref>http://www.sadatgraythwaite.com</ref> * Falcon Street: [[North Sydney Sewer Vent]]<ref name=nswshr-1641>{{cite NSW SHR|5053880|Sewer Vent|hr=01641|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> * 283a Miller Street: [[St Leonards Park]]<ref name=nswshr-1941>{{cite NSW SHR|5062353|St Leonards Park|hr=01941|fn=EF12/13999|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> * 6 Napier Street: ''[[Don Bank]]''<ref name=nswshr-31>{{cite NSW SHR|5045059|Don Bank|hr=00031|fn=EF14/5065; S90/6103; HC 32194|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> * 92-94 Pacific Highway: [[North Sydney Post Office]]<ref name=nswshr-1417>{{cite NSW SHR|5051506|North Sydney Post Office|hr=01417|fn=H00/00159|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> * 44 Union Street: ''[[Kailoa]]''<ref name=nswshr-179>{{cite NSW SHR|5045373|Kailoa|hr=00179|fn=S90/05907 & HC 32406|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref>
The following buildings are heritage-listed on other heritage registers:<ref>The Heritage of Australia, Macmillan Company, 1981, p.2/45-47</ref> * Chinese Christian Church, Alfred Street * [[Christ Church, Lavender Bay|Christ Church]], Walker and Lavender Streets * Church of England Rectory, Lavender Street * Houses: 11–37 Walker Street and 20–30 Walker Street * Mercedes, 9 Walker Street * St Francis Xavier's War Memorial Church, Mackenzie Street * St Francis Xavier's Presbytery, Mackenzie Street * St Francis Xavier's Church School Hall, Mackenzie Street * St Peter's Presbyterian Church and Manse, [[Blues Point Road]] * St Thomas's Church of England, West and Church Streets * St Thomas's Kindergarten Hall, Church and McLaren Streets * St Thomas's Church Rectory, McLaren Street * Woodstock, Pacific Highway<ref>[http://www.environment.nsw.gov.au/heritageapp/ViewHeritageItemDetails.aspx?ID=2180782 State Heritage Register]</ref>
==Commercial area== [[File:Ark-Coca Cola Place, viewed from Mount St April 2012.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Ark-Coca Cola Place]] [[File:Nth sydney nsw.jpg|thumb|North Sydney's high-rise commercial district]] The commercial district of North Sydney includes the second largest concentration of office buildings in [[New South Wales]],{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}} with a large representation from the advertising and information technology industries. Advertising, marketing businesses and associated trades such as printing have traditionally dominated the business life of the area though these have been supplanted to a certain extent by information technology businesses. Corporations whose offices are in North Sydney include, [[Cisco Systems]], [[Vocus Communications]], [[NBN Co]], [[Novell]], [[Sun Microsystems]], [[AGL Energy|AGL]], [[Hyundai]], [[Australian Associated Motor Insurers Limited|AAMI]], [[Sophos]], [[Symantec]], [[Nando's]], [[Vodafone]] NAB and until October 2007, [[Optus]].
Unlike other major suburban hubs within the Sydney metropolitan area, North Sydney has limited shopping facilities and almost no Sunday trading. There are four supermarkets ([[Aldi]], [[IGA (Australian supermarket group)|IGA]] , Coles and Woolworths Metro). The main shopping complex is the Greenwood Plaza, which is connected to [[North Sydney railway station|North Sydney station]].<ref>http://www.greenwoodplaza.com.au</ref> [[Berry Square, New South Wales|Berry Square]] is another shopping centre in Berry Street, formerly known as North Sydney Shopping World.<ref>http://www.northsydneysw.com.au</ref>
==Population== According to the {{CensusAU|2016}}, there were 7,705 residents in North Sydney. 48.1% of residents were born in Australia. The most common countries of birth were England 5.5%, India 4.3%, China 3.6%, New Zealand 3.2% and United States 1.9%. 63.6% of residents spoke only English at home. Other languages spoken at home included Mandarin 4.1%, Cantonese 2.9%, Hindi 2.0%, Spanish 1.7% and Japanese 1.7%. The most common responses for religion in North Sydney were No Religion 36.7% and Catholic 21.4%.<ref name=Census2016/>
==Transport== North Sydney is directly linked to the Sydney CBD by road and rail across the [[Sydney Harbour Bridge]]. [[North Sydney railway station]] is on the [[North Shore, Northern & Western Line]] of the [[Sydney Trains]] network. Bus services by [[State Transit Authority|State Transit]] are heavily present in Blue Street, connecting train and bus services towards North Sydney's neighbouring suburbs as well as connecting train services to Richmond via City from the T1 North Shore & Northern Lines. The [[Warringah Freeway]] links North Sydney south to the Sydney CBD and north to [[Chatswood, New South Wales]]. High Street, [[North Sydney ferry wharf|North Sydney wharf]] is a wharf stop on the Neutral Bay ferry service, which is part of the [[Sydney Ferries]] network. It is possible to walk from parts of North Sydney to the city centre in less than 30 minutes, by way of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
==Places of worship== [[Image:St Marys North Sydney 1.jpg|St Mary's Church|thumb]] Churches include St Mary's Catholic Church on Miller Street, St Francis Xavier's War Memorial Church in Mackenzie Street, [[St Thomas' Anglican Church, North Sydney|St Thomas Anglican Church]] on West and Church Streets, [[Christ Church, Lavender Bay|Christ Church]] on Walker and Lavender Streets, St Peter's Presbyterian Church and Manse on Blues Point Road and Chinese Christian Church on Alfred Street.
A [[ISKCON Temple Sydney|Hare Krishna temple]] is located on the corner of Falcon Street and Miller Street.<ref>http://www.iskcon.com.au</ref>
==Schools== Primary schools include [[North Sydney Demonstration School]], [[Mosman Preparatory School]] and St Marys Primary School.
High schools include the public [[North Sydney Boys High School]] and [[North Sydney Girls High School]], [[Cammeraygal High School]], the Catholic [[Marist College North Shore]] and [[Monte Sant' Angelo Mercy College]] and independent schools [[Wenona School]] and [[Sydney Church of England Grammar School]] (Shore).
[[St Aloysius' College (Sydney)|St Aloysius' College]] of Milson's Point and [[Loreto Kirribilli]] are also within the confines of the North Sydney [[Local government in Australia|local government area]]. [[Post-secondary]] education providers include the [[Australian Catholic University]], [[APM College of Business and Communication]], [[Raffles College of Design and Commerce]], [[Walker and Miller Training]] and [[Billy Blue College of Design]].
==Landmarks== [[Image:WWI Field Gun 316.JPG|thumb|A WWI German Field Gun in [[St Leonards Park]]. The State War Trophy Committee allocated the gun to Council in 1921. It was unveiled by Major-General Sir [[Granville Ryrie]][http://www.northsydney.nsw.gov.au/resources/documents/33_setinstone.pdf].]] * [[North Sydney Post Office]] * [[North Sydney Oval]] * [[Stanton Library]] *Brett Whiteley Square *Museum at [[Mary MacKillop]] Place, which tells the story of Australia's first [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholic]] saint * [[Don Bank|Don Bank Museum]], devoted to the history of the local area *Greenwood Plaza shopping complex (built under the former public school, founded 1878 and renamed after its Principal) * [[North Sydney railway station]] * [[Victoria Cross railway station]] (under construction) *Independent Theatre *Walker Street Cinema (closed)
==Sport and recreation== St Leonards Park which includes [[North Sydney Oval]] is the suburbs major recreation area, popular among joggers and those wishing to walk their dogs. North Sydney Ovals are notably cricket pitches during the summer and the home ground for the Northern Suburbs Rugby Union Club and the North Sydney Bears Rugby League Club during the winter.
The Norths Pirates Junior Rugby Union Club, is North Sydneys local junior village rugby union team who play all home games at Tunks Park in the adjoining suburb of Cammeray together with North Sydney Brothers, a junior rugby league club and the rugby league teams of Marist College North Shore.
* [[North Sydney Bears]] ([[rugby league]] team based in the area) * [[North Sydney Cricket Club]] * [[North Sydney Chess Club]] * Norths Pirates Junior Rugby Union<ref>See {{cite web |url=http://www.northspirates.rugbynet.com.au/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628141939/http://www.northspirates.rugbynet.com.au/ |archivedate=28 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> * [[Northern Suburbs Rugby Club]] * [[UTS Northern Suburbs Athletic Club]] * [[Gordon-North Sydney Hockey Club]]
During the [[2000 Summer Olympics]], the city was the starting point of the [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Olympics|marathon]] course that would end {{convert|26.2|mi|km|abbr=on}} later at the [[Stadium Australia|Olympic Stadium]] in Sydney.<ref>[http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/2000/2000v1.pdf 2000 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. p. 106.</ref>
* North Sydney Symphony Orchestra
==Notable people== * [[Billy Blue]], a convict after whom several places were named, such as [[Blues Point]] * [[Theodora Cowan]], Australia's first locally born sculptress, was living at 84 Berry Street when she died. * [[Antonella Gambotto-Burke]], an author, born at the Mater Hospital, North Sydney * [[Henry Lawson]], a poet and short-story author * [[Kel Nagle]], a golfer who won the [[1960 Open Championship]]
==Governance== The local government area of [[North Sydney Council]] includes the suburb of North Sydney and the surrounding suburbs of [[Crows Nest, New South Wales|Crows Nest]], [[Waverton, New South Wales|Waverton]], [[Neutral Bay, New South Wales|Neutral Bay]], [[McMahons Point, New South Wales|McMahons Point]], [[Kirribilli, New South Wales|Kirribilli]], [[Cremorne, New South Wales|Cremorne]] (divided between North Sydney & Mosman) and [[Cammeray]].
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:North Sydney Post Office-1.jpg|North Sydney Post Office File:Upton Grange North Sydney.jpg| Upton Grange, designed by [[William Wardell]] Image:Mary Mackillop Memorial Chapel, Mount Street, North Sydney, New South Wales, Sydney - Wiki0152.jpg|Mary Mackillop Memorial Chapel, Mount Street Image:St Francis Xavier Church, Mackenzie Street, North Sydney, New South Wales, Sydney - Wiki0156.jpg|St Francis Xavier Church Image:St Peters Church North Sydney.jpg|St Peter's Church Image:St Thomas North Sydney 1.jpg|St Thomas's Church File:North Sydney Farmers Market.jpg|North Sydney farmers market </gallery>

{{Infobox company | name = RJMetrics | logo = RJMetrics Logo.png | caption = RJMetrics company logo | type = Private [[Startup company|startup]] | foundation = [[Philadelphia, PA]] (2008) | founder = Jake Stein and Robert J. Moore | location_city = [[Philadelphia, PA]] | location_country = U.S. | industry = [[Computer software]] | num_employees = 71 (September 2014) | homepage = [http://www.rjmetrics.com rjmetrics.com] }} '''RJMetrics''' is an [[United States|American]] [[software company]] headquartered in [[Philadelphia, PA]]. The company offers big data analytics to small and midsize businesses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/201211/elizabeth-woyke/big-data-for-small-businesses.html |title=Big Data for Small Businesses |publisher=Inc. |date=2012-10-31}}</ref>
==History== RJMetrics was founded in 2008 by Jake Stein and Robert J. Moore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/rjmetrics |title=CrunchBase |publisher=Crunchbase |accessdate=2014-09-26}}</ref> The company had over 300 customers as of September 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dataconomy.com/rjmetrics-bags-16-5-million-in-series-b-funding/ |title=RJMetrics bags $16.5 Million in Series B Funding |publisher=Dataconomy |date=2014-09-16}}</ref>
===Funding=== RJMetrics was a [[bootstrapped]] company<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/20/business/smallbusiness/self-finance-or-raise-money-a-quandary-for-start-ups.html?pagewanted=all |title=Self Finance or Raise Money? A Quandary for Start Ups |publisher=New York Times |date=2013-06-19}}</ref> until it received its first round of funding in 2012. The seed round was $1.2 million and came from Red Swan Ventures, Vision Ventures, SoftTech VC, Zelkova Ventures, Lerer Ventures, and SV Angel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/rjmetrics-1-million-jason-goldberg-sv-angel-2012-1 |title=After Three years of Bootstrapping, RJMetrics Raises $1.2 Million from Fab's CEO and SoftTech |publisher=Business Insider |date=2012-01-03}}</ref> In May 2013, RJMetrics received its Series A funding of $6.25 million from Trinity Ventures and SoftTech VC.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/15/business-intelligence-startup-rjmetrics-raises-6-5m-from-trinity-ventures-for-ecommerce-boom/ |title=RJMetrics Raises $6.5 Million from Trinity Ventures for Ecommerce Boom |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2013-05-15}}</ref>
In September 2014, RJMetrics received its Series B funding of $16.5 million from SoftTech VC, Trinity Ventures, and August Capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/09/15/rjmetrics-series-b/ |title=Business Analytics Company RJMetrics Raises $16.5M Round Led By August Capital |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2014-09-15}}</ref> To-date, the Series B funding is one of the biggest rounds of funding received by a Philadelphia-based IT startup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://technical.ly/philly/2014/09/15/rjmetrics-16-2m-series-b/ |title=RJMetrics Just Raised $16.5M |publisher=Technically Philly |date=2014-09-15}}</ref>
===Acquisition=== In August 2016, [[Magento]] acquired RJMetrics, and [[Stitch, Inc.]] was spun out as an independent company, with the same investors as RJMetrics.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}}
==Platform== RJMetrics is a [[software as a service]] business intelligence platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enterpriseappstoday.com/business-intelligence/startup-spotlight-rjmetrics-offers-analytics-for-everyone.html |title=Startup Spotlight: RJMetrics Offers Analytics for Everyone |publisher=Enterprise Apps Today |date=2014-05-23}}</ref> In July 2014 RJMetrics announced the v2 release of its product and rebranded as an analytics platform.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inside-bigdata.com/2014/07/16/rjmetrics-releases-complete-analytics-platform-online-businesses/ |title=RJMetrics Releases Complete Analytics Platform for Online Businesses |publisher=Inside Big Data |date=2014-07-16}}</ref> The release included improvements to every major part of the software. * Analytic Warehouse: Built on [[Amazon Redshift]] * Transformation Cluster: Built on top of [[Hadoop]] * Visualization Interface: Allows users to perform [[cohort analysis]], calculate repeat event probability, and combine data from multiple sources
==Data journalism== RJMetrics has received a significant amount of press for their [[data journalism]]. Notable coverage includes: * The Wall Street Journal covering RJMetrics’ analysis of Crunchbase<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2012/08/13/study-examines-clubby-world-of-venture-capital/ |title=Study Examines the Clubby World of Venture Capital |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |date=2013-07-12}}</ref> * Fast Company covering RJMetrics’ analysis of Airbnb<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1835654/airbnb-numbers-85-users-inactive |title=Airbnb By the Numbers: 85% of Users Inactive? |publisher=Fast Company |date=2012-04-27}}</ref> * Forbes covering RJMetrics’ analysis of the ALS ice bucket challenge<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/cherylsnappconner/2014/09/03/were-the-ice-buckets-worth-it-new-and-deeper-analytics-say-yes/ |title= Were the Ice Buckets Worth It? New and Deeper Analytics Say 'Yes' |publisher=Forbes |date=2014-09-03}}</ref> * TechCrunch covering RJMetrics’ analysis of the Biz Stone’s Jelly App<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/01/14/jelly-sees-100k-questions-in-first-week-says-rjmetrics-of-which-25-received-answers/ |title=Jelly Sees 100k Questions In First Week Says RJMetrics, Of Which 25% Received Answers |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2014-01-14}}</ref>
In 2012, comedian [[Daniel Tosh]] covered RJMetrics' analysis of Chatroulette<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tosh.cc.com/blog/2010/03/18/where-are-the-perverts |title=Where Are the Perverts?! |publisher=Tosh.0 Blog |date=2010-03-18}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.rjmetrics.com/ Official Website]
